alert.note: Alert for Haywood; Jackson (North Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Greenville-Spartanburg (Western North Carolina and Northwest South Carolina)
info.headline: Flood Advisory issued July 10 at 2:18PM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 815 PM EDT THIS EVENING... * WHAT...Nuisance to minor flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...A portion of western North Carolina, including the following counties, southwest Haywood, northern Jackson and east-central Swain. * WHEN...Until 815 PM EDT Sunday. * IMPACTS...Rapid rises in small headwater streams will result in dangerous flows over low-water crossings. Some low-water crossings may become impassable. Expect small driveway culverts to become overwhelmed and possibly compromised by high drainage flow due to excessive runoff. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 210 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen over the past 1-2 hours. Nuisance to Minor flooding is imminent portions of southwest Haywood, northern Jackson and east-central Swain County. Areas of greatest concern are along Dicks Creek near Dillsboro, Scotts Creek near Sylva, Dark Ridge Creek, Soco Creek east of Cherokee, Jonathans Creek near Maggie Valley, Richland Creek southwest of Waynesville, and the West Fork Pigeon River near Sunburst. Residents along these streams and associated smaller drainages should be prepared to seek higher ground due to rapid rises and scattered bankfull exceedances. - Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are possible over the area. This additional rain will increase excessive runoff and may exacerbate ongoing flooding or cause new areas of flooding to develop. If this rainfall materializes, a portion or all of the Advisory area may be upgraded to a Flash Flood Warning. Please stay weather aware. - Some locations that may experience flooding include... Sylva, Waynesville, Bryson City, Cherokee, Lake Junaluska, Maggie Valley, Balsam, Webster, Dillsboro, Oconaluftee, and Deep Creek. - Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: In hilly terrain there are hundreds of low water crossings which are potentially dangerous in heavy rain. Do not attempt to cross flooded roads. Find an alternate route. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. It is important to know where you are relative to streams, rivers, or creeks which can become killers in heavy rains. Campers and hikers should avoid streams or creeks.
